posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello there mfhansen, welcome aboard!

Excellent first crack(s) at building - certainly better than mine was - and clearly presented. Kudos!

If I might mention a couple of things...

I don't know if you're aware of this or not, but you'll be finishing HotU at around level 27-8, so, unless you're thinking of taking the builds forward somewhere else, you'll want to get what you can from those levels. Unfortunately, unless we do some restructuring, you won't be Dev Critting or Epic Dodging during the campaigns. If you'd prefer to sacrifice those elements, other options are available.

Afraid I'm no expert on several elements of these 2 builds, but one thing I do know about Cleric is that you actually want to have a maximum pre-epic BAB of 15. Yes, I know, that's only 3 attacks per round. However, Divine Power gives you an extra attack per round at full AB, so you end up with 4 attacks and 2 of them are at full AB, which is better than a pure Fighter-type. Thus, you might think about swapping either Cleric 12 or CoT 4 for Bard 5.

I've got to be somewhere else right now, but I'll come back to you, if that's okay.

Cheers

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Welcome mf_hansen!
Stagmeister already pointed out that HotU ends at level 27 or 28, and unless you plan on taking the builds elsewhere, you should plan the builds for lvl 28. 

What you try to do here is taking the good old fighter/rogue/wizard/cleric quartet and melt it all together into two character builds.
When I see Cleric 20, Wizard 20 and AA 7 in level 40 builds, I think there should have been more.
Rogue 13 and Bard 16 are often just right.
CoT 4 is a filler for a couple of extra feats, slightly better saves and a little extra BAB.
My benevolent feedback is that I think you try to cram too much into the builds. It makes them weaker and makes them mature very late - too late for a lvl 28 campaign.

So how to build a duo?
You want magic, healing, melee, ranged attacks and rogue skills.

You will be able to play the game without investing anything in healing: No class spells, no heal skills, no whatsoever. There are plenty of heal kits to cure poison and disease. There are potions for almost every healing spell. And there are restoration and antidote potions. There are also scrolls of all levels of restoration, raise dead and resurrection. And there are scrolls that cure other ailments and curses.

And regardless I think one of your characters should be a cleric. Clerics have great melee prowess, and have spells that in most cases make them better warriors than the warrior classes. They are also very strong against undead. Cleric spells give the protections you need, and you can attack undead with your healing spells! The Mass heal spell works as an area of attack spell, far better than Turn undead.
You may sprinkle the build slightly with bard for skill dumps, or with fighter or CoT for extra feats. But building up Cleric quickly is the most important. I would take no less than 24 cleric levels in a level 28 build made for this purpose. Then you get a very powerful "spell-sword".

The other build should be a rogue and I would focus on the rogue class early on to get many skill points and be able to build up a little SA damage and the essential rogue skills and social skills. Here you have greater freedom with multiclassing.
If you want an archer, give AA priority and take no more than 2 levels of wizard .The second wizard level is at full BAB and Rogue 8/ Wizard 2/AA 10 has BAB 17 whereas Rogue 9/ Wizard 1/ AA 10 only has BAB 16! I would start with Rogue 7/ Wizard 2 before taking AA and take the 8th rogue level later for a skill dump. In epic levels I would take a couple of rogue levels more for skill dumps. There is also the option to aim at rogue 13 and ED at level 27. 

The rogue can use scrolls and other caster items with the UMD skill. If you have a level of wizard, you have free access to all wizard restricted scrolls and items. But the most powerfull magic user in this duo will be the cleric above!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
And if you were prepared to go with Mick's advice about the Cleric you wouldn't need to worry about all the feats you need for Dev Crit, freeing up several feats (at least Power Attack, Cleave and Great Cleave, but possibly also Martial Weapon Prof and Toughness - but I'll come to Toughness later). This would help in getting Blind Fight and Divine Might. So, remaining as human, and taking 17 or 18 levels of Cleric pre-epic you'd still have one spare feat as a minimum.

It would also give you more freedom with your stats. You wouldn't need to go for so much Str (if it helps, Divine Power also raises your Str to 18 if it's below that), and, if you only take a few levels of Bard, you could also dump Cha (down to 8 if you took Cleric at level 1, 11 if not). This would enable you to really bump Wis, as well as getting your Con more comfortable - which is where my earlier line about maybe losing Toughness comes in. Maybe something like STR 12, DEX 12, CON 14, WIS 16 (22 or 23), INT 14, CHA 8.

Just a few thoughts...

Cheers

Here are a couple builds that I think would work well together, and I actually did play the AA build in SoU and HotU (and Sands of Fate).  You could easily add Dev Crit to the Cleric by replacing Toughness with Great Cleave, and replacing 2 of the Great Strength feats with Overwhelming Crit and Dev Crit.

If you follow HotU with the Sands of Fate series, you will go all the way to level 40.  I was given this recommendation early on, and I have never played HotU without Sands of Fate afterwards.  Well, there was that one time I played evil and followed HotU with The Gods Themselves, but then I made a good version of that same build (a WM build) for Sande of Fate.  I just realized that the WB build would also be a good partner for the AA.  I have never had as easy a time in HotU than with that build.  Actually, I'll include a different WM build because that one had Rogue, and you don't need 2 Rogues.

Even though Half-Orc gets +2 STR, he pays for it heavily with both -2 INT and -2 CHA, and has no other special race features.  I think it is a bad deal.  Here is another approach to getting Dev Crit by the end of HotU, and both this and the Elven Guardian can go to level 40 in Sands of Fate, in case you decide to continue after HotU.  This is another build I actually played.

If you made this a Half-Orc instead of Human, you would be paying a high price for that +2 STR (44 instead of 42 at level 40).  You would lose a feat at level 1, you would lose 2 full skills, and you would be ineligible to take Improved Knockdown because your INT would be too low until level 21, when you get +2 INT from RDD 9.  It is totally not worth it.  If you want. you could use the large phenotype, make his skin green, and roleplay a Half-Orc.  I wouldn't, but you do you.

posts.author: mf_hansen
posts.content:
Sweet build! The extra RDD levels certainly bring the STR for devastating goodness, and the extra CON is excellent for more hitpoints. Later casting but no biggie once SoF hits.

Sorry for the late reply, we got a bit carried away and made a head-start in SoU with the version 3 builds already :) just struggling a bit with AMD graphics performance in old OpenGL.

We are thinking we may as well try version 3 as-is, then possibly reroll between the expansions (apparently there's also The Nether Scrolls on NWvault tying SoU and HotU together).

Between all the builds you all helped with and the experiences we make in SoU, along with the excellent Cleric guide and build suggestions, I'm sure we'll have a smashing time.

Thanks all for the help!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Longarm is the name of the bow, if I remember correctly.

For chapter 1 of Sands of Fate, you will need protection from fire damage (hot desert sun), and for chapter 2 (and 3), you will need a weapon that does acid damage (trolls) and a ranged weapon with fire or cold damage (green slime).
